quiz.title: APC Political Knowledge Quiz
quiz.description: Comprehensive quiz on APC, Nigerian Politics, Political History & Global Politics

questions.question: What does APC stand for?
questions.explanation: APC is the All Progressives Congress, formed in 2013 as a merger of several opposition parties in Nigeria.

questions.question: In what year was the All Progressives Congress (APC) formed?
questions.explanation: The APC was formed in February 2013 through a merger of opposition parties including ACN, ANPP, CPC, and APGA members.

questions.question: Which of these parties was NOT part of the merger that formed APC in 2013?
questions.explanation: PDP was the ruling party at the time and did not merge. APC was formed from ACN, ANPP, CPC, and elements of APGA.

questions.question: Who was the first presidential candidate of APC in 2015?
questions.explanation: Muhammadu Buhari was APC's presidential candidate in 2015 and won the election.

questions.question: In which year did APC first win Nigeria's presidential election?
questions.explanation: APC won the 2015 presidential election with Muhammadu Buhari as candidate.

questions.question: Who is the current chairman of APC (as of 2024)?
questions.explanation: Uche Nwosu was elected National Chairman of APC. Party leadership positions may change.

questions.question: Who was APC's presidential candidate in the 2019 election?
questions.explanation: Muhammadu Buhari retained APC's presidential ticket in 2019 and was re-elected.

questions.question: Who was APC's presidential candidate in the 2023 election?
questions.explanation: Bola Tinubu was APC's presidential candidate in 2023 and won the election.

questions.question: What is APC's party symbol?
questions.explanation: The elephant is APC's official party symbol.

questions.question: How many states has APC won in the 2023 gubernatorial elections?
questions.explanation: APC won 18 out of 36 states in the 2023 gubernatorial elections.

questions.question: In what year did Nigeria gain independence from Britain?
questions.explanation: Nigeria gained independence on October 1, 1960, becoming a sovereign nation.

questions.question: Who was Nigeria's first Prime Minister after independence?
questions.explanation: Abubakar Tafawa Balewa served as Prime Minister from 1957 to 1966.

questions.question: Who was Nigeria's first President after becoming a republic in 1963?
questions.explanation: Nnamdi Azikiwe became President when Nigeria became a republic in 1963.

questions.question: What event marked the beginning of Nigeria's military rule?
questions.explanation: The first military coup occurred on January 15, 1966, ending the First Republic.

questions.question: Who led the first military coup in Nigeria in 1966?
questions.explanation: Major General Aguyi Ironsi led the first military coup on January 15, 1966.

questions.question: When did the Nigerian-Biafran Civil War occur?
questions.explanation: The Nigerian-Biafran Civil War lasted from July 1967 to January 1970.

questions.question: Who was the military head of state during the Nigerian-Biafran Civil War?
questions.explanation: Yakubu Gowon was Head of State from August 1966 to July 1975 and led the country during the civil war.

questions.question: What was the immediate cause of the Nigerian-Biafran Civil War?
questions.explanation: The Eastern Region, led by Col. Emeka Ojukwu, seceded as the Republic of Biafra, triggering the civil war.

questions.question: In what year did Nigeria return to civilian rule after Yakubu Gowon's military regime?
questions.explanation: Nigeria returned to civilian rule in 1979 under President Shehu Shagari after military transition.

questions.question: Who was Nigeria's first elected civilian president after the civil war?
questions.explanation: Shehu Shagari won the 1979 elections and served as president from 1979 to 1983.

questions.question: How many times has Nigeria written new constitutions?
questions.explanation: Nigeria has had constitutions in 1963, 1966, 1989, 1993, and 1999.

questions.question: Which military leader returned Nigeria to democratic rule in 1999?
questions.explanation: General Abdulsalami Abubakar oversaw the transition to democracy and handed over to Olusegun Obasanjo in 1999.

questions.question: Who was the first elected president of Nigeria's Fourth Republic (1999)?
questions.explanation: Olusegun Obasanjo was elected president in 1999, beginning Nigeria's Fourth Republic.

questions.question: For how long did Olusegun Obasanjo serve as president?
questions.explanation: Obasanjo served as president from 1999 to 2007, completing two four-year terms.

questions.question: Who succeeded Olusegun Obasanjo as president in 2007?
questions.explanation: Umaru Musa Yar'Adua was elected president in 2007 under the PDP.

questions.question: What is significant about Nigeria's 1993 presidential election?
questions.explanation: The June 12, 1993 elections were widely regarded as Nigeria's freest and fairest elections, though they were annulled by the military.

questions.question: Who won the controversial June 12, 1993 presidential election?
questions.explanation: Moshood Abiola was widely believed to have won the June 12, 1993 elections, which were annulled by the military government.

questions.question: In which year was June 12 changed from Democracy Day to Democracy Day in Nigeria?
questions.explanation: June 12 was moved from May 29 as Democracy Day in 2019 to commemorate the June 12, 1993 elections.

questions.question: How many states did Nigeria have at independence in 1960?
questions.explanation: Nigeria had 3 regions (Northern, Western, and Eastern) at independence, later reorganized into states.

questions.question: When was Nigeria reorganized from regions to states?
questions.explanation: Nigeria was reorganized from 3 regions to 12 states in 1966 by the military government.

questions.question: How many states does Nigeria have as of 2024?
questions.explanation: Nigeria has 36 states plus the Federal Capital Territory (FCT), making 37 federal units.

questions.question: How many local government areas (LGAs) does Nigeria have?
questions.explanation: Nigeria has 774 Local Government Areas (LGAs) plus 6 Area Councils in FCT.

questions.question: What is the tenure of a Nigerian president?
questions.explanation: Nigerian presidents serve 4-year terms with a maximum of two consecutive terms.

questions.question: What is the maximum number of consecutive presidential terms allowed in Nigeria?
questions.explanation: Presidents can serve a maximum of two consecutive 4-year terms under the 1999 Constitution.

questions.question: Who was Nigeria's president before Bola Tinubu?
questions.explanation: Muhammadu Buhari served as president from 2015 to 2023 before Bola Tinubu.

questions.question: In what year did Bola Tinubu become president of Nigeria?
questions.explanation: Bola Tinubu was inaugurated as president on May 29, 2023.

questions.question: Who is the vice president under Bola Tinubu?
questions.explanation: Kashim Shettima serves as Vice President under President Bola Tinubu.

questions.question: What is Nigeria's primary legislative body called?
questions.explanation: Nigeria's legislature is the National Assembly, comprising the Senate and House of Representatives.

questions.question: How many senators are there in Nigeria's Senate?
questions.explanation: Nigeria has 109 senators: 3 from each of the 36 states and 1 from FCT.

questions.question: How many members are in Nigeria's House of Representatives?
questions.explanation: The House of Representatives has 360 members representing various constituencies.

questions.question: Who is the current president of the Nigerian Senate?
questions.explanation: Godswill Akpabio was elected Senate President in 2023.

questions.question: Who is the Speaker of the House of Representatives?
questions.explanation: Tajudeen Abbas serves as Speaker of the House of Representatives.

questions.question: What is the name of the ruling party before APC's 2015 victory?
questions.explanation: The People's Democratic Party (PDP) ruled Nigeria from 1999 to 2015.

questions.question: How long did PDP rule Nigeria before APC took over?
questions.explanation: PDP ruled from 1999 to 2015, a period of 16 years.

questions.question: Which party won the 2023 presidential election after APC?
questions.explanation: APC won the 2023 presidential election with Bola Tinubu as candidate.

questions.question: Who was the main opposition candidate in the 2023 presidential election?
questions.explanation: Atiku Abubakar was the PDP's presidential candidate in 2023.

questions.question: Which institution is responsible for organizing elections in Nigeria?
questions.explanation: INEC (Independent National Electoral Commission) organizes and manages all elections in Nigeria.

questions.question: Who is the current chairman of INEC?
questions.explanation: Mahmood Yakubu serves as Chairman of INEC.

questions.question: What is the minimum voting age in Nigeria?
questions.explanation: Nigerian citizens must be at least 18 years old to vote.

questions.question: In which year were Nigeria's 2023 elections conducted?
questions.explanation: Nigeria's 2023 general elections were held in February 2023.

questions.question: How many members are in the United Nations?
questions.explanation: The UN has 193 member states as of 2024.

questions.question: In what year was the United Nations established?
questions.explanation: The United Nations was established in 1945 after World War II.

questions.question: What is the largest economy in the world by GDP?
questions.explanation: The United States has the largest economy in the world by nominal GDP.

questions.question: Which country is a permanent member of the UN Security Council?
questions.explanation: China is one of five permanent members of the UN Security Council (P5).

questions.question: How many permanent members are in the UN Security Council?
questions.explanation: The UN Security Council has 5 permanent members: US, UK, France, Russia, and China.

questions.question: What is the European Union primarily known as?
questions.explanation: The EU is a political and economic union of member states.

questions.question: How many member states are in the African Union?
questions.explanation: The African Union has 54 member states representing all African nations.

questions.question: When was the African Union established?
questions.explanation: The African Union was established in 2002, replacing the Organization of African Unity (OAU).

questions.question: What is ECOWAS?
questions.explanation: ECOWAS (Economic Community of West African States) is a regional bloc of 16 West African countries.

questions.question: How many countries are members of ECOWAS?
questions.explanation: ECOWAS has 16 member states including Nigeria, Ghana, Senegal, and others.

questions.question: What does NATO stand for?
questions.explanation: NATO stands for North Atlantic Treaty Organization, a military alliance.

questions.question: In which year was the Universal Declaration of Human Rights adopted?
questions.explanation: The Universal Declaration of Human Rights was adopted by the UN in 1948.

questions.question: What is the headquarters of the United Nations located?
questions.explanation: The UN headquarters is in New York City.

questions.question: Which country has the largest population in the world?
questions.explanation: India has surpassed China to become the most populous country in the world.

questions.question: What does IMF stand for?
questions.explanation: IMF stands for International Monetary Fund, a global financial institution.

questions.question: When was the World Bank established?
questions.explanation: The World Bank was established in 1944 at Bretton Woods Conference.

questions.question: What does WTO stand for?
questions.explanation: WTO stands for World Trade Organization, regulating international trade.

questions.question: How many countries are in the G20?
questions.explanation: The G20 comprises 20 major economies plus the EU.

questions.question: Is Nigeria a member of the G20?
questions.explanation: Nigeria is not a member of the G20, which comprises major advanced and emerging economies.

questions.question: What is the primary focus of the Commonwealth?
options: Political association of former British colonies
questions.explanation: The Commonwealth is a political association of mostly former British Empire territories.

questions.question: What is APC's primary policy focus?
questions.explanation: APC's ideology emphasizes progressivism, democratic governance, and national development.

questions.question: What major reform did Muhammadu Buhari's APC government initiate?
questions.explanation: APC under Buhari removed fuel subsidies in 2016, a major but controversial policy.

questions.question: What security challenge did APC government prioritize addressing?
questions.explanation: APC made combating the Boko Haram insurgency a key security priority.

questions.question: What economic initiative did Bola Tinubu's administration launch?
questions.explanation: Tinubu initiated economic reforms including naira devaluation and subsidy removal.

questions.question: What is APC's stance on democracy?
options: Supports democratic governance and free elections
questions.explanation: APC is committed to democratic governance, free elections, and constitutional rule.

questions.question: What infrastructure project did APC prioritize?
questions.explanation: APC prioritized major infrastructure projects including the Lagos-Ibadan railway.

questions.question: What anti-corruption agency has APC government supported?
questions.explanation: APC supports anti-corruption agencies like EFCC (Economic and Financial Crimes Commission) and ICPC.

questions.question: What is APC's approach to privatization?
questions.explanation: APC supports market-oriented policies including strategic privatization of state enterprises.

questions.question: What international partnership has APC government emphasized?
options: Strategic partnerships with African and global institutions
questions.explanation: APC emphasizes strategic partnerships within Africa and the global community.

questions.question: What social program initiative has APC promoted?
options: Social Investment Programme (SIP) for poverty reduction
questions.explanation: APC implemented the Social Investment Programme targeting poverty reduction and social welfare.

questions.question: What electoral system does Nigeria use for presidential elections?
questions.explanation: Nigeria uses a runoff system where a candidate must win 25% in 24 states plus a majority nationally.

questions.question: How often are general elections held in Nigeria?
questions.explanation: General elections are held every 4 years in Nigeria.

questions.question: What is Nigeria's voting system called?
questions.explanation: Nigeria uses both manual paper ballots and increasingly electronic voting systems in some areas.

questions.question: How many senatorial districts does Nigeria have?
questions.explanation: Nigeria has 36 senatorial districts (3 per state) plus 1 FCT district.

questions.question: When is Nigeria's Democracy Day celebrated?
questions.explanation: Democracy Day is celebrated on June 12, commemorating the June 12, 1993 elections.

questions.question: What is the minimum age to contest for president in Nigeria?
questions.explanation: A candidate must be at least 35 years old to run for president in Nigeria.

questions.question: What is the minimum age to contest for state governor?
questions.explanation: Gubernatorial candidates must be at least 30 years old.

questions.question: How long is a senator's term in Nigeria?
questions.explanation: Nigerian senators serve 4-year terms.

questions.question: How long is a House member's term?
questions.explanation: Members of the House of Representatives serve 4-year terms.

questions.question: What is a ward in Nigeria's political structure?
questions.explanation: A ward is the smallest electoral and administrative unit in Nigeria's structure.
